Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Novel Bioprocess for Natural Gas Conversion
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercialization potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is to produce an important platform chemical, hexanoic acid. Currently, the 6-carbon compounds are difficult to attain since crude petroleum contains just a small fraction in this carbon range as part of light naphtha. Most of the 6-carbon compounds are produced via multiple steps that constitute conversion of olefins derived from light naphtha. The various 6-carbon compounds include hexanol, hexene, caprolactam and hexa-easters. All of these compounds are direct derivatives of hexanoic acid. The proposed technology will manufacture hexanoic acid using a novel bioprocess, which will provide an alternative source for this chemical at a reduced cost. Current direct market uses of hexanoic acid include artificial flavors, rubber chemicals, varnish driers, resins and pharmaceuticals. It can be converted to hexene, caprolactam (nylon feedstock). These value added รก-olefins, polymers and premium lubricant industry feedstocks, become excellent candidates for early commercialization. In addition, hexanoic acid can be converted to decane, a jet fuel component via decarboxylation and radical coupling chemistry. Thus, longer-term prospects exist for using the proposed innovation to penetrate a >$300 Billion jet fuel market.

This STTR Phase I project proposes to develop a novel microbial strain to convert methanol to hexanoic acid. The primary objective of this project is to demonstrate techno-economic feasibility of methanol conversion to hexanoic acid. The overall estimated carbon yield and energy efficiency are significantly higher compared to state of the art. The biological pathway consists of two elements added to an acetogenic host: (1) Addition of methanol oxidation reactions to provide reductant; and (2) Extension of the chain length of the acid formed. Methanol oxidation will use well-known pathways from known organisms and reactions capable of operation without oxygen in the utilization of methanol and H2/CO2. The chain length will be extended by using the basic pathway of Clostridium and known enzymes to form hexanoic acid. At the end of the project, a novel strain will be developed that can convert methanol to hexanoic acid in a single step. A preliminary assessment of the overall process will be performed and compared to the current commercial manufacturing process.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary objective of this proposal was to demonstrate techno-economic feasibility of the overall process. The anaerobic conversion process demonstrated very high carbon yield and high energy efficiency. The innovation  led to novel strain development using genome sequence information developed by the team. The proposed innovation leads to net consumption of carbon dioxide. Microbial production of organic acids conserves redox and forms ATP relative to production of alcohols, which allowed a more robust cell performance.  Anaerobic production process will reduce overall plant capital expenditure and operating costs as well as enable higher carbon conversion efficiency upon commercialization in future. Finally, fed-batch operation that allows the reuse of biocatalyst for multiple production cycles will significantly reduce the manufacturing cost as the innovation proceeds towards commercialization.

The product of proposed innovation, butyric acid has a number of premium applications. It forms a building block for materials in a number of industries including bulk and specialty chemical industries. The bulk applications include animal feed and chemical intermediates. Specialty chemicals applications include flavors, fragrances and pharmaceuticals. In addition, the specialty polymers poly hydroxyl butyrate and cellulose acetate butyrate are produced with butyric acid. Butadiene, a direct product of butyric acid forms a building block of styrene-butadiene-rubber, poly-butadiene, styrene-butadiene-latex and nitrile rubber. Butadiene-based rubbers have been substitutes for natural rubber in many applications. The global butyric acid market has been growing 15% annually. Applications in the fuels market includes direct blending in the gasoline pool as butanol, a direct derivative of butyric acid. The proposed innovation can be deployed at smaller scales suitable for distributed natural gas conversion and hence utilize the otherwise flared natural gas. Upon commercialization, the proposed innovation will lead to creation of jobs in the United States. 


Last Modified: 03/31/2016
Modified by: Mukund Karanjikar
